qas.question: How many different ways can a species be added to the endangered list?
What federal program is used to list a species?
How long is the screening period of an individual's or organization's petition to add a species to the list
In the case of vertebrates, what is the most lenient interpretation of "species"?
How many ways FWS list a species?
Who does the FWS or NMFS have to petition to list a species?
How long does an individual have to petition the FWS?
In what case does a distinct population segment not count?
What is another name for the United States Fish and Wildlife Service (FWS)?

context: A species can be listed in <a0_0><b4_0>two<b4_0/> ways<a0_0/>. The United States Fish and Wildlife Service (FWS) or NOAA Fisheries (also called the <b8_0>National Marine Fisheries Service<b8_0/>) can directly list a species through its <a1_0>candidate assessment program<a1_0/>, or <b5_0>an individual or organizational<b5_0/> petition may request that the FWS or NMFS list a species. A "species" under the act can be a true taxonomic species, a subspecies, or in the case of <b7_0>vertebrates<b7_0/>, <a3_0>a "distinct population segment."<a3_0/> The procedures are the same for both types except with the person/organization petition, there is a <a2_0><b6_0>90-day<b6_0/> screening period<a2_0/>.
